title: BSNL-MTNL Merged To Get Back On Track And Fight Private Telecom Companies Together
text:
BSNL-MTNL Merged To Get Back On Track And Fight Private Telecom Companies Together

BSNL-MTNL Merged To Get Back On Track And Fight Private Telecom Companies Together

After consecutive loss-making quarters, the government today decided to merge BSNL and MTNL to become a stronger force against the competition in the telecom industry.

Reuters

The government is also bringing along a new strategy to get these companies back on track in the form of sovereign bonds, monetising assets and VRS or voluntary retirement schemes for employees.

As per the new decision, BSNL will absorb MTNL, post which MTNL will act as a subsidiary of BSNL. Oddly enough, MTNL is listed on NSE (National Stock Exchange) but is suffering from poor net worth. BSNL, on the other hand, remains unlisted.

BSNL who suffered an approximate loss of Rs 14,000 crores has still not paid salaries to their employees. It spends an average of 850 crores monthly with 1.76 lakh staff members on its payroll.

The government plans on bringing a four-step revival strategy for these telecom brands. Telecom minister Ravi Shankar Prasad has stated that the government wishes to make the state-owned duo more competitive by investing Rs 29,937 crores.

According to Ravi Shankar Prasad, the government plans to raise Rs 15,000 crore with the help of the aforementioned sovereign bonds. Assets amounting to Rs 38,000 crores will be monetisated in four years.

Reuters

For the dated government telecom agencies to compete against privately-owned Reliance Jio, Vodafone and Airtel, Prasad announced that they will be allotted 4G spectrum. The allotment for this would be based on the prices in 2016.

As mentioned earlier, Ravi Shankar Prasad has also promised to bring in VRS for its employees. He plans to bring lucrative VRS package for employees working in BSNL and MTNL.

In an example, he stated that an employee above the age of 53 and a half who decides to opt for VRS will be offered 125 percent remuneration of salary, pension and gratuity till he reaches 60 years of age.
